newsitem.title: USA: CSCE cocoa ends broadly lower, focus on May-July.
newsitem.headline: CSCE cocoa ends broadly lower, focus on May-July.

text.p: CSCE cocoa futures ended broadly lower in sluggish trading Wednesday, dragged down by speculative selling of the nearby May/July switch ahead of the spot month's delivery period, dealers said.
"There was weakness on rollover ahead of (May) first notice day," one trader said. "People were cleaning up thier May positions."

Spot May cocoa settled down $14 at $1,400 a tonne, toward the bottom of its $1,417 to $1,397 range. Most-active July slid $16 to $1,439 after posting trades from $1,457 to $1,435. The outer months lost $14 to $16.
The market headed lower at the outset on the heels of losses in the London cocoa market overnight, traders said. Downward momentum accelerated after July slipped chart support at $1,444, they said.

Dealings centered on the nearby switch, as speculators adjusted positions before May goes into notice period on April 17. May's discount to second-month July pulled back to $39 at the close, down from $41 on Tuesday.
May open interest fell 2,458 lots Tuesday, to 4,854 lots, while July's open interest rose by 1,483 lots to 32,548 lots.
Technically, near-term support was seen at last Friday's low of $1,433, with resistance pegged at $1,457 to $1,459, with a large chart gap looming at $1,480 to $1,504.

On the fundamental side, news Bahia 1996/97 cocoa arrivals totalled 2,834,701 million 60-kg bags by the week ending April 6 compared with 2,626,668 bags by April 7 of last year had little impact on the market, traders said.
The U.S. first-quarter grind data is due Friday at 0845 EDT, but traders expect the data to have little effect on prices. Analysts' grind forecasts ranged from flat to up five percent.
Volume reached an estimated 12,028 lots, with switches accounting for much of the day's turnover, traders said.
